title: Sunday Night fails to mention its own role in Molly Meldrum's feud with Elton John
text:
Molly Meldrum opened the lid on his his long-running feud with Elton John on Channel Seven's Sunday Night this weekend.

But many viewers are questioning why the program failed to mention it's own role in the feud.

Back in 2012, Sunday Night aired a discussion between Molly and Elton that they both thought was an off-the-record, in which the Rocket Man star labelled Madonna a 'fairground stripper' and a 'nightmare'.

Fancy that! Sunday Night failed to mention its own role in Molly Meldrum’s feud with Elton John over the weekend

Molly, who famously does not preview any of his celebrity interviews before they go to air, assumed the footage would never be used.

This incident caused a falling out between Molly and Elton that has never been healed.

Despite this, Sunday Night was conspicuously silent on its involvement in the saga.

Déjà vu? Back in 2012, Sunday Night aired a discussion between Molly and Elton that they both thought was an off-the-record, in which the Rocket Man star labelled Madonna a 'fairground stripper' and a 'nightmare'

'Deceptive to viewers!' TV Blackbox's Robert McKnight Tweeted about Sunday Night's bizarre silence in its involvement in the feud on Monday

The program also chose not to replay footage from its own 2012 interview.

Instead, the story centred upon Molly giving a heartfelt apology to his former friend.

'We've had the most amazing journey for a long, long time. We've both through the ups and we've been through the downs,' the former Countdown presenter said of Elton.

'A friendship like ours is worth keeping forever': Molly gave a heartfelt apology to his former friend during his recent interview with Sunday Night (pictured: Elton John)

Becoming emotional, he added: 'A friendship like ours is worth keeping forever.'

Molly's interview came days after it was announced that Sunday Night had been axed amid poor ratings.

Sunday Night, which debuted in 2009, was named 'Australia's No. 1 public affairs program' in 2017.

Around this time, it had an average audience of 845,000 metro viewers, but this number has practically halved in two years.

Industry insiders said that recent declining ratings and expensive costs meant a cancellation was inevitable.
